== References == {{reflist}}
{{Messier Index}}

{{ Globular cluster | | name = [[w:Messier object|Messier]] 75 | image = [[image:Messier 75.jpg|300px]] | epoch = [[w:J2000]] | class = I | constellation = [[w:Sagittarius (constellation)|Sagittarius]] | ra = {{RA|20|06|04.75}}{{cite web | title=SIMBAD Astronomical Database | work=Results for NGC 6864 | url=http://simbad.u-strasbg.fr/Simbad | accessdate=2006-11-16}} | dec = {{DEC|-21|55|16.2}} | dist_ly = 67.5 [[w:light-year|kly]]{{Fact|date=February 2007}} | dist_pc = 20.7 [[w:parsec|kpc]] | appmag_v = +9.18 | size_v = 6′.8 | mass_kg = | mass_msol = | radius_ly = 67 lydistance × sin( diameter_angle / 2 ) = 67 ly. radius | v_hb = | age = | notes = | names = M75, [[w:New General Catalogue|NGC]] 6864, GCl 116 }} '''Messier 75''' (also known as '''M75''' or '''NGC 6864''') is a [[w:globular cluster]] in the [[w:constellation]] [[w:Sagittarius (constellation)|Sagittarius]]. It was discovered by [[w:Pierre Méchain]] in [[w:1780]] and included in [[w:Charles Messier]]'s catalog of [[w:comet]]-like objects that same year. M75 is at a distance of about 67,500 [[w:light year]]s away from [[w:Earth]] and its apparent size on the sky translates to a true radius of some 67 [[w:light year]]s. It is classified as class ''I'', meaning it is one of the more densely concentrated globular clusters known. The [[w:absolute magnitude]] of M75 is about -8.5 or some 180,000 more [[w:luminosity|luminous]] than the [[w:Sun]]. ==External links== * [http://www.seds.org/messier/m/m075.html Messier 75 @ SEDS Messier pages] * [http://venus.mporzio.astro.it/~marco/gc/cluster_4.php?ggc=M+75 Messier 75, Galactic Globular Clusters Database page] ==References==
{{Messier Index}}

{{Infobox galaxy | name = Cetus A | image = [[File:M77HunterWilson.jpg|250px]] | caption = Spiral Galaxy M77 | epoch = [[w:J2000]] | type = (R)SA(rs)b{{cite web | title=NASA/IPAC Extragalactic Database | work=Results for NGC 1068 | url=http://nedwww.ipac.caltech.edu/ | accessdate=2006-11-18 }} | ra = {{RA|2|42|40.7}} | dec = {{DEC|-00|00|48}} | dist_ly = [[w:1 E23 m|47.0]] [[w:light-year|Mly]] (14.4 [[w:parsec|Mpc]]) | z = 1137 ± 3 km/[[w:second|s]] | appmag_v = 9.6 | size_v = 7′.1 × 6′.0 | constellation name = [[w:Cetus]] | notes = One of the biggest galaxies
of [[w:Messier]]'s catalog.
Inclination estimated to be 40°.{{cite web | title=Pattern Speeds BIMA-SONG Galaxies with Molecule-Dominated ISMs Using the Tremaine-Weinberg Method | work=(Schinnerer et al. 2000) | url=http://arxiv.org/abs/astro-ph/0406426 | accessdate=2006-08-31 }} | names = Cetus A, M77, [[w:New General Catalogue|NGC]] 1068, [[w:Uppsala General Catalogue|UGC]] 2188, [[w:Principal Galaxies Catalogue|PGC]] 10266, [[w:Atlas of Peculiar Galaxies|Arp]] 37 }} '''Messier 77''' (also known as '''''[[w:New General Catalogue|NGC]] 1068''''') is a [[w:spiral galaxy|barred spiral galaxy]] about 47 million [[w:light-year]]s away in the [[w:constellation]] [[w:Cetus]]. Messier 77 is an [[w:active galaxy]] with an [[w:Active Galactic Nucleus]] (AGN), which is obscured from view by astronomical dust at visible wavelengths. The diameter of the molecular disk and hot plasma associated with the obscuring material was first measured at radio wavelengths by the [[w:VLBA]] and [[w:VLA]]. The hot dust around the nucleus was subsequently measured in the mid-infrared by the [[w:Mid-IR Interferometric instrument|MIDI]] instrument at the [[w:VLT]]I. It is the brightest{{citation | url = http://adsabs.harvard.edu/abs/1973ApJ...181...31D | title = Southern Galaxies.VI. Luminosity Distribution in the Seyfert Galaxy NGC 1566 | last1 = de Vaucouleurs | first1 = Gérard | authorlink1 = Gérard de Vaucouleurs | year = 1973 | date = [[w:April 1]] [[w:1973]] | journal = Astrophysical Journal | volume = 181 | pages = 31–50 | doi = 10.1086/152028 }} [[w:Seyfert galaxy]] and is of type 2.{{cite web | title=Pattern Speeds BIMA-SONG Galaxies with Molecule-Dominated ISMs Using the Tremaine-Weinberg Method | work=Bland-Hawthorn et al. (1997) | url=http://arxiv.org/abs/astro-ph/0406426 | accessdate=2006-08-31 }} [[image:M77HunterWilson.jpg|thumb|left|250px| M77, amateur image. Courtesy of Hunter Wilson]] Messier 77's diameter is a 170,000 light-years. ==History== Messier 77 was discovered by [[w:Pierre Méchain]] in [[w:1780]], who originally described it as a nebula. Méchain then communicated his discovery to [[w:Charles Messier]], who subsequently listed the object in his [[w:Messier Catalogue|catalog]].{{cite book | author=K. G. Jones | year=1991 | title=Messier's Nebulae and Star Clusters | edition= 2nd | publisher=Cambridge University Press | location=Cambridge | isbn=0-521-37079-5 }} Both Messier and [[w:William Herschel]] described this galaxy as a star cluster. Today, however, the object is known to be a galaxy. ==External links== * [http://www.seds.org/messier/m/m077.html Spiral Galaxy M77 @ SEDS Messier pages] * [http://www.vlba.nrao.edu/imgmonth/N1068/ VLBA image of the month: radio continuum and water masers of NGC 1068] * [http://www.eso.org/outreach/press-rel/pr-2004/pr-10-04.html Press release about VLTI observations of NGC 1068] ==References== {{reflist}} {{Messier Index}}

revision.comment: Removing "M78_sdss.jpg", it has been deleted from Commons by [[commons:User:Juliancolton|Juliancolton]] because: Per [[commons:Commons:Deletion_requests/File:M78_sdss.jpg]].

revision.text:
{{ Globular cluster | | name = [[w:Messier object|Messier]] 79 | image = [[image:M79a.jpg|280px]] | epoch = [[w:J2000]] | class =V | constellation = [[w:Lepus constellation|Lepus]] | ra = {{RA|05|24|10.59}}{{cite web | title=SIMBAD Astronomical Database | work=Results for NGC 1904 | url=http://simbad.u-strasbg.fr/Simbad | accessdate=2006-11-17}} | dec = {{DEC|-24|31|27.3}} | dist_ly = 41 [[w:light-year|kly]]{{Fact|date=February 2007}} | dist_pc = 12 [[w:parsec|kpc]] | appmag_v = +8.56 | size_v =8,7' | mass_kg = | mass_msol = | radius_ly = | v_hb = | age = | notes = | names = M79, [[w:New General Catalogue|NGC]] 1904, GCl 10 }} '''Messier 79''' (also known as '''M79''' or '''NGC 1904''') is a [[w:globular cluster]] in the [[w:Lepus constellation]]. It was discovered by [[w:Pierre Méchain]] in [[w:1780]]. M79 is at a distance of about 41,000 [[w:light year]]s away from [[w:Earth]] and 60,000 light years away from the [[w:Galactic Center]]. Like [[w:Messier 54]] (the other extragalactic globular on Messier's list), it is thought that M79 is not native to the [[w:Milky Way]] galaxy at all, but instead to the [[w:Canis Major Dwarf Galaxy]] which is currently experiencing a very close encounter with the Milky Way, one it is unlikely to survive intact. This is, however, a contentious subject as astronomers are still debating the nature of the Canis Major dwarf galaxy itself[http://adsabs.harvard.edu/abs/2007A%26A...472L..47L Re-affirming the connection between the Galactic stellar warp and the Canis Major over-density]; care must therefore be taken when associating any object with the Canis Major dwarf. ==References==
==External links== * [http://www.seds.org/messier/m/m079.html Messier 79, SEDS Messier pages] * [http://venus.mporzio.astro.it/~marco/gc/cluster_4.php?ggc=M+79 Messier 79, Galactic Globular Clusters Database page] {{Messier Index}}

{{ Globular cluster | | name = [[w:Messier object|Messier]] 80 | image = [[image:A_Swarm_of_Ancient_Stars_-_GPN-2000-000930.jpg|300px]] |caption= A [[w:Hubble Space Telescope]] (HST) image of M80.
Credit: HST/[[w:NASA]]/[[w:ESA]]. | epoch = [[w:J2000]] | class = II | ra = {{RA|16|17|02.51}}{{cite web | title=SIMBAD Astronomical Database | work=Results for NGC 6093 | url=http://simbad.u-strasbg.fr/Simbad | accessdate=2006-11-16}} | dec = {{DEC|-22|58|30.4}} | constellation = [[w:Scorpius]] | dist_ly = 32.6 [[w:light-year|kly]] | dist_pc = 10 [[w:parsec|kpc]] | appmag_v = +7.87 | size_v = 10′.0 | mass_kg = | mass_msol = | radius_ly = 48 ly | v_hb = | age = | notes = | names = M80, NGC 6093, GCl 39 }} '''Messier 80''' (also known as '''M80''' or '''NGC 6093''') is a [[w:globular cluster]] in the [[w:constellation]] [[w:Scorpius]]. It was discovered by [[w:Charles Messier]] in [[w:1781]]. M80 is located midway between α Scorpii ([[w:Antares]]) and [[w:Beta Scorpii|β Scorpii]] in a field in the Milky Way that is rich in [[w:nebula]]e. It can be viewed with modest amateur [[w:telescope]]s as a mottled ball of light. With an apparent diameter of about 10' and at an estimated distance of 32,600 [[w:light-year]]s, M80's spatial diameter is about 95 light-years and contains several hundred thousand [[w:star]]s. It is among the more densely populated globular clusters in the [[w:Milky Way Galaxy]]. M80 contains a relatively large amount of ''[[w:blue straggler]]s'', stars that appear to be much younger than the cluster itself. It is thought these stars have lost part of their outer layers due to close encounters with other cluster members or perhaps the result of collisions between stars in the dense cluster. Images from the [[w:Hubble Space Telescope]] have shown districts of very high blue straggler densities, suggesting that the center of the cluster is likely to have a very high capture and collision rate. On [[w:May 21]], [[w:1860]], a [[w:nova]] was discovered in M80 that attained a [[w:apparent magnitude|magnitude]] of +7.0. The nova, [[w:variable star]] designation ''T Scorpii'', reached an [[w:absolute magnitude]] of -8.5, briefly outshining the entire cluster. ==External links== * [http://www.seds.org/messier/m/m080.html Messier 80, SEDS Messier pages] * [http://venus.mporzio.astro.it/~marco/gc/cluster_4.php?ggc=M+80 Messier 80, Galactic Globular Clusters Database page] * [http://antwrp.gsfc.nasa.gov/apod/ap990707.html Astronomy Picture of the Day description] * [http://www.spacetelescope.org/images/html/opo9926a.html Messier 80 at ESA/Hubble] ==References==
{{Messier Index}}

{{Infobox galaxy | name = [[w:Messier object|Messier]] 81{{cite journal | author=Jensen, Joseph B.; Tonry, John L.; Barris, Brian J.; Thompson, Rodger I.; Liu, Michael C.; Rieke, Marcia J.; Ajhar, Edward A.; Blakeslee, John P. | title=Measuring Distances and Probing the Unresolved Stellar Populations of Galaxies Using Infrared Surface Brightness Fluctuations | journal=Astrophysical Journal | month=February | year=2003 | volume=583 | issue=2 | pages=712–726 | url=http://adsabs.harvard.edu/abs/2003ApJ...583..712J | doi=10.1086/345430 }}{{cite journal | author=I. D. Karachentsev, O. G. Kashibadze | title=Masses of the local group and of the M81 group estimated from distortions in the local velocity field | journal=Astrophysics | year=2006 | volume=49 | issue=1 | pages=3–18 | url=http://adsabs.harvard.edu/cgi-bin/nph-bib_query?bibcode=2006Ap.....49....3K | doi=10.1007/s10511-006-0002-6 }} | image = [[image:Messier_81_HST.jpg|300px]] | caption = A [[w:Hubble Space Telescope]] (HST) image of Messier 81.
Credit: HST/[[w:NASA]]/[[w:ESA]]. | epoch = [[w:J2000]] | constellation name = [[w:Ursa Major]]{{cite book | author=R. W. Sinnott, editor | title= The Complete New General Catalogue and Index Catalogue of Nebulae and Star Clusters by J. L. E. Dreyer | year=1988 | publisher=Sky Publishing Corporation and Cambridge University Press | isbn=0-933-34651-4}} | ra = {{RA|09|55|33.2}} {{cite web | title=NASA/IPAC Extragalactic Database | work=Results for NGC 3031 | url=http://nedwww.ipac.caltech.edu/ | accessdate=2006-11-10}} | dec = {{DEC|+69|3|55}} | appmag_v = 7.89 | type = SA(s)ab, [[w:LINER]] | names = [[w:New General Catalogue|NGC]] 3031, [[w:Uppsala General Catalogue|UGC]] 5318, [[w:Principal Galaxies Catalogue|PGC]] 28630, Bode's Galaxy{{cite web | title=SIMBAD Astronomical Database | work=Results for NGC 3031 | url=http://simbad.u-strasbg.fr/Simbad | accessdate=2006-11-10}} }} '''Messier 81''' (also known as '''NGC 3031''' or '''Bode's Galaxy''') is a [[w:spiral galaxy]] about [[w:1 E22 m|12 million]] [[w:light-year]]s away in the [[w:constellation]] [[w:Ursa Major]]. M81 is one of the most striking examples of a [[w:grand design spiral galaxy]], with near perfect arms spiraling into the very center. Because of its proximity to [[w:Earth]], its large size, and its [[w:active galactic nucleus]] (which harbors a [[w:supermassive black hole]]) Messier 81 is a popular galaxy to study in professional [[w:astronomy]] research. The galaxy's large size and relatively low apparent magnitude (lower magnitude implies higher brightness) also make it a popular target for [[w:amateur astronomy]] observations.{{cite book | author=S. J. O'Meara | year=1998 | title=The Messier Objects | publisher=Cambridge University | location=Cambridge | isbn=0-521-55332-6}} ==Discovery== Messier 81 was first discovered by [[w:Johann Elert Bode]] in [[w:1774]].{{cite book | author=K. G. Jones | year=1991 | title=Messier's Nebulae and Star Clusters | edition= 2nd | publisher=Cambridge University Press | location=Cambridge | isbn=0-521-37079-5}} Consequently, the galaxy is sometimes referred to as "Bode's Galaxy". In [[w:1779]], [[w:Pierre Méchain]] and [[w:Charles Messier]] reidentified Bode's object, which was subsequently listed in the [[w:Messier Catalogue]]. ==Dust emission== [[image:Messier81 highres.jpg|300px|thumb|left|An [[w:infrared]] image of Messier 81 taken by the [[w:Spitzer Space Telescope]]. The blue colors represent stellar emission observed at 3.6 [[w:micrometre|μm]].{{cite journal | author=S. P. Willner, M. L. N. Ashby, P. Barmby, G. G. Fazio, M. Pahre, H. A. Smith, R. C. Kennicutt, Jr., D. Calzetti, D. A. Dale, B. T. Draine, M. W. Regan, S. Malhotra, M. D. Thornley, P. N. Appleton, D. Frayer, G. Helou, S. Stolovy, and L. Storrie-Lombardi | title=Infrared Array Camera (IRAC) Observations of M81 | journal=Astrophysical Journal Supplement Series | year=2004 | volume=154 | pages=222–228 | url=http://adsabs.harvard.edu/abs/2004ApJS..154..222W | doi=10.1086/422913 }} The green colors represent 8 μm emission originating primarily from [[w:polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbon]]s in the [[w:interstellar medium]]. The red colors represent 24 μm emission originating from heated dust in the interstellar medium.{{cite journal | author=K. D. Gordon, P. G. Pérez-González, K. A. Misselt, E. J. Murphy, G. J. Bendo, F. Walter, M. D. Thornley, R. C. Kennicutt, Jr., G. H. Rieke, C. W. Engelbracht, J.-D. T. Smith, A. Alonso-Herrero, P. N. Appleton, D. Calzetti, D. A. Dale, B. T. Draine, D. T. Frayer, G. Helou, J. L. Hinz, D. C. Hines, D. M. Kelly, J. E. Morrison, J. Muzerolle, M. W. Regfan, J. A. Stansberry, S. R. Stolovy, L. J. Storrie-Lombardi, K. Y. L. Su, E. T. Young | title=Spatially Resolved Ultraviolet, Hα, Infrared, and Radio Star Formation in M81 | journal=Astrophysical Journal Supplement Series | year=2004 | volume=154 | pages=215–221 | url=http://adsabs.harvard.edu/abs/2004ApJS..154..215G | doi=10.1086/422714 }} Credit: [[w:NASA]]/[[w:JPL]]-[[w:Caltech]]/K. Gordon/S. Willner/N.A. Sharp.]] Most of the emission at [[w:infrared]] wavelengths originates from [[w:interstellar dust]].{{cite journal | author=P. G. Pérez-González, R. C. Kennicutt, Jr., K. D. Gordon, K. A. Misselt, A. Gil de Paz, C. W. Engelbracht, G. H. Rieke, G. J. Bendo, L. Bianchi, S. Bossier, D. Calzetti, D. A. Dale, B. T. Draine, T. H. Jarrett, D. Hollenbach, M. K. M. Prescott | title=Ultraviolet through Far-Infrared Spatially Resolved Analysis of the Recent Star Formation in M81 (NGC 3031) | journal=Astrophysical Journal | year=2006 | volume=648 | pages=987–1006 | url=http://adsabs.harvard.edu/abs/2006ApJ...648..987P | doi=10.1086/506196 }} This interstellar dust is found primarily within the galaxy's [[w:spiral arm]]s, and it has been shown to be associated with [[w:star formation]] regions. The general explanation is that the hot, short-lived [[w:blue star]]s that are found within star formation regions are very effective at heating the dust and hence enhancing the infrared dust emission from these regions. ==Supernova== Only one [[w:supernova]] has been detected in Messier 81.{{cite web | title=NASA/IPAC Extragalactic Database | work=Results for extended name search on NGC 3031 | url=http://nedwww.ipac.caltech.edu/ | accessdate=2007-02-27}} The supernova, named [[w:SN 1993J]], was discovered on 28 March 1993 by F. Garcia in Spain.{{cite journal | author=J. Ripero, F. Garcia, D. Rodriguez, P. Pujol, A. V. Filippenko, R. R. Treffers, Y. Paik, M. Davis, D. Schlegel, F. D. A. Hartwick, D. D. Balam, D. Zurek, R. M. Robb, P. Garnavich, B. A. Hong | title=Supernova 1993J in NGC 3031 | journal=IAU Circular | year=1993 | volume=5731 | url=http://adsabs.harvard.edu/abs/1993IAUC.5731....1R}} At the time, it was the second brightest supernova observed in the twentieth century.{{cite journal | author=B. P. Schmidt, R. P. Kirshner, R. G. Eastman, R. Grashuis, I. dell'Antonio, N. Caldwell, C. Foltz, J. P. Huchra, A. A. E. Milone | title=The unusual supernova SN1993J in the galaxy M81 | journal=Nature | year=1993 | volume=364 | pages=600–602 | url=http://adsabs.harvard.edu/abs/1993Natur.364..600S | doi=10.1038/364600a0 }} The spectral characteristics of the supernova changed over time. Initially, it looked more like a type II supernova (a supernovae formed by the explosion of a giant star) with strong [[w:hydrogen]] [[w:spectral line]] emission, but later the hydrogen lines faded and strong [[w:helium]] spectral lines appeared, making the supernova look more like a type Ib.{{cite journal | author=A. V. Filippenko, T. Matheson, L. C. Ho | title=The "Type IIb" Supernova 1993J in M81: A Close Relative of Type Ib Supernovae | journal=Astrophysical Journal Letters | year=1993 | volume=415 | pages=L103–L106 | url=http://adsabs.harvard.edu/abs/1993ApJ...415L.103F | doi=10.1086/187043 }} Moreover, the variations in SN 1993J's luminosity over time were not like the variations observed in other type II supernovae{{cite journal | author=P. J. Benson, W. Herbst, J. J> Salzer, G. Vinton, G. J. Hanson, S. J. Ratcliff, P. F. Winkler, D. M. Elmegreen, F. Chromey, C. Strom, T. J. Balonek, B. G. Elmegreen | title=Light curves of SN 1993J from the Keck Northeast Astronomy Consortium | journal=Astronomical Journal | year=1994 | volume=107 | pages=1453–1460 | url=http://adsabs.harvard.edu/abs/1994AJ....107.1453B | doi=10.1086/116958 }}{{cite journal | author=J. C. Wheeler, E. Barker, R. Benjamin, J. Boisseau, A. Clocchiatti, G. de Vaucouleurs, N. Gaffney, R. P. Harkness, A. M. Khokhlov, D. F. Lester, B. J> Smith, V. V. Smith, J. Tomkin | title=Early Observations of SN 1993J in M81 at McDonald Observatory | journal=Astrophysical Journal | year=1993 | volume=417 | pages=L71–L74 | url=http://adsabs.harvard.edu/abs/1993ApJ...417L..71W | doi=10.1086/187097 }} but did resemble the variations observed in type Ib supernovae.{{cite journal | author=M. W. Richmond, R. R. Treffers, A. V. Filippenko, Y. Palik, B. Leibundgut, E. Schulman, C. V. Cox | title=UBVRI photometry of SN 1993J in M81: The first 120 days | journal=Astronomical Journal | year=1994 | volume=107 | pages=1022–1040 | url=http://adsabs.harvard.edu/abs/1994AJ....107.1022R | doi=10.1086/116915 }} Hence, the supernova has been classified as a "type IIb", a transitory class between type II and type Ib. The scientific results from this supernova suggested that type Ib and Ic supernovae were actually formed through the explosions of giant stars through processes similar to what takes place in type II supernovae.{{cite journal | author=A. V. Filippenko, T. Matheson, A. J. Barth | title=The peculiar type II supernova 1993J in M81: Transition to the nebular phase | journal=Astronomical Journal | year=1994 | volume=108 | pages=2220–2225 | url=http://adsabs.harvard.edu/abs/1994AJ....108.2220F | doi=10.1086/117234 }} The supernova was also used to estimate a distance of 8.5 ± 1.3 [[w:light year|Mly]] (2.6 ± 0.4 [[w:parsec|Mpc]]) to Messier 81. ==Nearby galaxies and galaxy group information== [[image:AnttlersM81M82.jpg|400px|thumb|right|M81 (left) and [[w:Messier 82|M82]] (right). M82 is one of two galaxies that is strongly gravitationally interacting with M81. The other, [[w:NGC 3077]], is located above the top edge of this image. Credit:Scott Anttila.]] Messier 81 is the largest galaxy in the [[w:M81 Group]], a [[w:galaxy groups and clusters|group]] of 34 galaxies located in the constellation Ursa Major.{{cite journal | author=I. D. Karachentsev | title=The Local Group and Other Neighboring Galaxy Groups | journal=Astronomical Journal | year=2005 | volume=129 | pages=178–188 | url=http://adsabs.harvard.edu/abs/2005AJ....129..178K | doi=10.1086/426368 }} The distance from the Earth to the group is approximately 11.7 [[w:light-year|Mly]] (3.6 [[w:parsec|Mpc]]), making this one of the closest groups to the [[w:Local Group]], which contains the [[w:Milky Way]]. M81 is [[w:interacting galaxy|gravitationally interacting]] with [[w:Messier 82]] and [[w:NGC 3077]].{{cite journal | author=M. S. Yun, P. T. P. Ho, K. Y. Lo | title=A high-resolution image of atomic hydrogen in the M81 group of galaxies | journal=Nature | year=1994 | volume=372 | pages=530–532 | url=http://adsabs.harvard.edu/abs/1994Natur.372..530Y | doi=10.1038/372530a0 }} The interactions have stripped some [[w:hydrogen]] gas away from all three galaxies, leading to the formation of filamentary gas structures in the group. Moreover, the interactions have also caused some [[w:interstellar medium|interstellar gas]] to fall into the centers of Messier 82 and NGC 3077, which has led to strong [[w:starburst galaxy|starburst activity]] (or the formation of many stars) within the centers of these two galaxies. ==Amateur astronomy information== Messier 81 is located approximately 10° northwest of [[w:Alpha Ursae Majoris]] along with several other galaxies in the [[w:Messier 81 Group]].{{cite book | author=D. J. Eicher | year=1988 | title=The Universe from Your Backyard | publisher=Cambridge University Press | location=Cambridge | isbn=0-521-36299-7}} Messier 81 and Messier 82 can both be viewed easily using [[w:binoculars]] and small [[w:telescope]]s. The two objects are generally not observable to the unaided eye, although highly experienced amateur astronomers may be able to see Messier 81 under exceptional observing conditions. Telescopes with [[w:aperture]]s of 8 [[w:inch]]es or larger are needed to distinguish structure in the galaxy. ==External links== * [http://www.seds.org/messier/m/m081.html M81, SEDS Messier pages] * [http://www.spitzer.caltech.edu/Media/releases/ssc2003-06/ssc2003-06d.shtml SST: Messier 81] * [http://antwrp.gsfc.nasa.gov/apod/ap020620.html APOD: Bright Galaxy M81 (6/20/02)] * [http://www.nightskyinfo.com/archive/m81_m82_galaxies NightSkyInfo.com - M81, Bode's Galaxy] * [http://www.spacetelescope.org/images/archive/freesearch/m81/viewall/1 ESA/Hubble images of M81] * [http://ryutao.main.jp/english/st2k_m81_l.html Galaxy Messier 81 (Bode's Galaxy)] * [http://gallery.spitzer.caltech.edu/Imagegallery/image.php?image_name=ssc2003-06d Spitzer Image Gallery] * [http://www.helkit.com/astro/galaxy/m81-82.shtml Helkit Observatory] * [http://www.stargazer-observatory.com/m81.html M81 imaged through a semiprofessional amateur-telescope] ==References== {{reflist|2}} {{Messier Index}}

{{Infobox galaxy | name = [[w:Messier object|Messier]] 82 | image = [[image:M82 Chandra HST Spitzer.jpg|300px]] |caption = A combined [[w:Hubble Space Telescope|Hubble]]/[[w:Spitzer Space Telescope|Spitzer]]/[[w:Chandra X-Ray Observatory|Chandra]] image of M 82. | credit = [[w:NASA]]/[[w:JPL]]-Caltech/STScI/CXC/UofA/[[w:ESA]]/AURA/JHU. | epoch = [[w:J2000]] | type = I0<ref name="ned">{{cite web | title=NASA/IPAC Extragalactic Database | work=Results for NGC 3034 | url=http://nedwww.ipac.caltech.edu/ | accessdate=2006-10-27 }}</ref> | ra = {{RA|09|55|52.2}}<ref name="ned" /> | dec = {{DEC|+69|40|47}}<ref name="ned" /> | dist_ly = [[w:1 E23 m|11.5 ± 0.8]] [[w:light-year|Mly]] (3.5 ± 0.3 [[w:parsec|Mpc]])<ref name="Karachentsevetal2006" /> | z = 203 ± 4 km/[[w:second|s]]<ref name="ned" /> | appmag_v = 9.3<ref name="ned" /> | size_v = 11′.2 × 4′.3<ref name="ned" /> | constellation name = [[w:Ursa Major]] | notes = Edge on starburst galaxy | names = [[w:New General Catalogue|NGC]] 3034, [[w:Uppsala General Catalogue|UGC]] 5322, [[w:Atlas of Peculiar Galaxies|Arp]] 337, Cigar Galaxy, [[w:Principal Galaxies Catalogue|PGC]] 28655<ref name="ned" /> }}
'''Messier 82''' (also known as '''NGC 3034''' or the '''Cigar Galaxy''') is the [[w:prototype galaxy|prototype]]<ref name="Barkeretal2008">{{citation | url = http://adsabs.harvard.edu/abs/2008A%26A...484..711B | year = 2008 | date = June 2008 | title = Star cluster versus field star formation in the nucleus of the prototype starburst galaxy M 82 | last1 = Barker | first1 = S. | last2 = de Grijs | first2 = R. | last3 = Cerviño | first3 = M. | journal = Astronomy and Astrophysics | volume = 484 | issue = 3 | pages = 711–720 | doi = 10.1051/0004-6361:200809653 }}</ref> nearby [[w:starburst galaxy]] about 12 million [[w:light-year]]s away in the [[w:constellation]] [[w:Ursa Major]]. The starburst galaxy is five times as bright as the whole [[w:Milky Way]] and one hundred times as bright as our galaxy's center.<ref name="Barkeretal2008" />
In 2005, the [[w:Hubble space telescope|Hubble]] revealed 197 young massive clusters in the starburst core.<ref name="Barkeretal2008" /> The average mass of these clusters is around 2{{e|5}} ''M''<sub>⊙</sub>, hence the starburst core is a very energetic and high-density environment.<ref name="Barkeretal2008" /> Throughout the galaxy's center, young stars are being born 10 times faster than they are inside our entire Milky Way Galaxy.<ref>[http://newswise.com/articles/view/519818/ Happy Sweet Sixteen, Hubble Telescope!] Newswise, Retrieved on [[w:July 30]], [[w:2008]].</ref>
==Messier 81 triggering starburst== [[image:M82(2).jpg|thumb|150px|left|Chandra X-ray Observatory image of the '''Cigar Galaxy''']] Forming a striking pair in small [[w:telescope]]s with nearby [[w:spiral galaxy|spiral]] [[w:Messier 81|M81]], M82 is being physically affected by its larger neighbor. Tidal forces caused by [[w:gravity]] have deformed this [[w:galaxy]], a process that started about 100 million years ago. This interaction has caused star formation to increase 10 fold compared to "normal" galaxies.
Recently, M82 has undergone at least one tidal encounter with M81 resulting in a large amount of gas being funneled into the galaxy's core over the last 200 Myr.<ref name="Barkeretal2008" /> The most recent such encounter is thought to have happened around 2–5{{e|8}} years ago and resulted in a concentrated starburst together with a corresponding marked peak in the cluster age distribution.<ref name="Barkeretal2008" /> This starburst ran for up to ~50 Myr at a rate of ~10 ''M''<sub>⊙</sub> per year.<ref name="Barkeretal2008" /> Two subsequent startbursts followed, the last (~4–6 Myr ago) of which may have formed the core clusters, both super star clusters (SSCs) and their lighter counterparts.<ref name="Barkeretal2008" />
Ignoring any difference in their respective distances from us, the centers of M81 and M82 are visually separated by about 130,000 light-years.<ref>Declination separation of 36′.87 and Right Ascension separation of 9′.5 gives via [[w:Pythagorean theorem]] a visual separation of 38′.07; Average distance of 11.65 Mly × sin(38′.07) = 130,000 ly visual separation.</ref> The actual separation is 300{{±|300|200}} kly.<ref>Separation = sqrt(D<sub>M81</sub><sup>2</sup> + D<sub>M82</sub><sup>2</sup> - 2 D<sub>M81</sub> D<sub>M82</sub> Cos(38′.07)) assuming the error direction is about the same for both objects.</ref><ref name="Karachentsevetal2006">{{cite journal | author=Karachentsev, I. D.; Kashibadze, O. G. | title=Masses of the local group and of the M81 group estimated from distortions in the local velocity field | journal=3 light years | year=2006 | volume=49 | issue=1 | pages=3–18 | url=http://adsabs.harvard.edu/cgi-bin/nph-bib_query?bibcode=2006Ap.....49....3K | doi=10.1007/s10511-006-0002-6 }}</ref>
==Starburst region== In the core of M82, the active starburst region spans a diameter of 500 pc. In optical, there are four high surface brightness regions or clumps (designated A, C, D, and E).<ref name="Barkeretal2008" /> These clumps correspond to known sources at [[w:X-ray]], [[w:infrared]], and [[w:astronomical radio source|radio]] frequencies.<ref name="Barkeretal2008" /> Consequently, they are thought to be the least obscured starburst clusters from our vantage point.<ref name="Barkeretal2008" /> M82's unique bipolar outflow (or 'superwind') appears to be concentrated on clumps A and C and fueled by the energy injected by [[w:supernova]] that occur about once every ten years.<ref name="Barkeretal2008" />
The [[w:Chandra X-ray Observatory]] detected fluctuating [[w:X-ray]] emissions from a location approximately 600 light-years away from the center of M82. Astronomers have postulated that this fluctuating emission comes from the first known [[w:intermediate-mass black hole]], of roughly 200 to 5000 [[w:solar mass]]es.<ref name="Patrunoetal2006">{{cite journal | author=Patruno, A.; Portegies Zwart, S.; Dewi, J.; Hopman, C. | title=The ultraluminous X-ray source in M82: an intermediate-mass black hole with a giant companion | journal=Monthly Notices of the Royal Astronomical Society: Letters | year=2006 | volume=370 | issue=1 | pages=L6–L9 | url=http://adsabs.harvard.edu/cgi-bin/nph-bib_query?bibcode=2005ApJ...628L..33M | doi=10.1111/j.1745-3933.2006.00176.x }}</ref> M82, like most galaxies, hosts a supermassive black hole at its center with a mass of approximately 3 x 10<sup>7</sup> solar masses as measured from stellar dynamics.<ref>{{cite journal | author = Gaffney, N. I., Lester, D. F., and Telesco, C. M. | title = "The stellar velocity dispersion in the nucleus of M82" | journal = [[w:Astrophysical Journal Letters]] | year = 1993 | month = April | volume = 407 | pages = L57–L60 | doi = 10.1086/186805 | url = http://adsabs.harvard.edu/abs/1993ApJ...407L..57G }}</ref>
==Structure== [[image:M82s.jpg|thumb|150px|left|M82 in a small telescope.]] M82 was previously believed to be an irregular galaxy. However, in [[w:2005]], two symmetric [[w:spiral arm]]s were discovered in the [[w:near-infrared]] (NIR) images of M82. The arms were detected by subtracting an [[w:axisymmetric]] exponential disk from the NIR images. These arms emanate from the ends of the NIR [[w:Barred spiral galaxy|bar]] and can be followed for the length of 3 [[w:Disc (galaxy)|disc]] scales. Even though the arms were detected in the NIR images, they are bluer than the disk. Assuming that the northern part of M82 is nearer to us, which most literature assumes, the observed sense of rotation implies trailing arms. Due to M82's high disk [[w:surface brightness]], nearly edge-on orientation (~80°)<ref name="Barkeretal2008" /> with respect to us, and the presence of a complex network of dusty filaments in optical images, the arms were not previously detected.<ref name="Mayyaetal2005">{{cite journal | author=Mayya, Y. D.; Carrasco, L.; Luna, A. | title=The Discovery of Spiral Arms in the Starburst Galaxy M82 | journal=The Astrophysical Journal | year=2005 | volume=628 | issue=1 | pages=L33–L36 | url=http://adsabs.harvard.edu/cgi-bin/nph-bib_query?bibcode=2005ApJ...628L..33M | doi=10.1086/432644 }}</ref>
==External links== {{commons|Messier 82}} * [http://www.seds.org/messier/m/m082.html M82, SEDS Messier pages] * [http://chandra.harvard.edu/photo/0094/index.html M82 at Chandra] * [http://www.spitzer.caltech.edu/Media/releases/ssc2006-09/index.shtml SST: Galaxy on Fire!] * [http://nedwww.ipac.caltech.edu/cgi-bin/nph-objsearch?objname=m82&extend=no&out_csys=Equatorial&out_equinox=J2000.0&obj_sort=RA+or+Longitude&of=pre_text&zv_breaker=30000.0&list_limit=5&img_stamp=YES M82 at NASA/IPAC EXTRAGALACTIC DATABASE] *[http://www.spacetelescope.org/images/archive/freesearch/m82/viewall/1 ESA/Hubble images of M82] * [http://www.dsi-astronomie.de/M82NAO8.html M82 The Cigar Galaxy]
==References== {{reflist|2}}
{{Messier Index}}

{{recipe}} [[Category:Mexican recipes]] [[Category:Salsa recipes]]
Here's a tip for making good omelets: Cook the things that you want cooked before you add it into the eggs, and have everything at room temperature.
== Ingredients == * 3 eggs, uncracked * 2-3 pinches fine sea salt * 1 habanero chile, finely minced and seeded if you like * 1/2 cup salsa, room temperature * 1 cup grated Monterrey Jack cheese, room temperature * 2 tbs fresh cilantro/coriander, finely chopped * Butter
== Procedure == #Cover eggs with warm but not scalding water. Let sit 5 minutes or until room temperature. #Beat eggs with salt. Set aside. #Combine chiles, salsa, cilantro, and cheese. Set aside. #Heat a large nonstick over medium high heat. Quickly swirl with butter and add eggs. Cook until egg is set and well browned on side facing pan. #Sprinkle salsa mixture evenly on uncooked side of egg. Fold in half and cook raw side until set and well browned. #Sprinkle with chopped cilantro and serve warm.

{{Infobox galaxy | name = [[w:Messier object|Messier]] 83 | image = [[image:MESSIER_083_ESO XXL.jpg|320px]] |caption = An [[w:ESO]] image of Messier 83.
Credit: ESO. | epoch = [[w:J2000]] | ra = {{RA|13|37|00.9}}{{cite web | title=NASA/IPAC Extragalactic Database | work=Results for NGC 5236 | url=http://nedwww.ipac.caltech.edu/ | accessdate=2006-12-08}} | dec = {{DEC|-29|51|57}} | type = SAB(s)c | dist_ly = [[w:1 E23 m|14.7]] [[w:light-year|Mly]] (4.5 [[w:parsec|Mpc]]){{cite journal | author=I. D. Karachentsev, M. E. Sharina, A. E. Dolphin, E. K. Grebel, D. Geisler, P. Guhathakurta, P. W. Hodge, V. E. Karachetseva, A. Sarajedini, P. Seitzer | title=New distances to galaxies in the Centaurus A group | journal=Astronomy and Astrophysics | year=2002 | volume=385 | pages=21–31 | url=http://adsabs.harvard.edu/abs/2002A&A...385...21K | doi=10.1051/0004-6361:20020042}} | z = 513 ± 2 km/[[w:second|s]] | appmag_v = 8.2 | size_v = 12′.9 × 11′.5 | constellation name = [[w:Hydra (constellation)|Hydra]] | names = [[w:New General Catalogue|NGC]] 5236, UGCA 366, [[w:Principal Galaxies Catalogue|PGC]]48082, Southern Pinwheel Galaxy,{{cite web | title=SIMBAD astronomical database | work=Results for M83 | url=http://simbad.u-strasbg.fr/simbad/ | accessdate=2007-05-02}} }} '''Messier 83''' (also known as the ''Southern Pinwheel Galaxy'', ''M83'' or ''NGC 5236'') is an [[w:intermediate spiral galaxy]] approximately 15 million [[w:light-year]]s away in the [[w:constellation]] [[w:Hydra (constellation)|Hydra]]. It is one of the closest and brightest [[w:Barred spiral galaxy|barred spiral galaxies]] in the sky, making it visible with [[w:binoculars]]. Six [[w:Supernova]]e ([[w:SN 1923A]], [[w:SN 1945B]], [[w:SN 1950B]], [[w:SN 1957D]], [[w:SN 1968L]] and [[w:SN 1983N]]) have been observed in M83. ==History== Pierre Mechain discovered M83 in 1752 at the [[w:Cape of Good Hope]].{{cite book | author=K. G. Jones | year=1991 | title=Messier's Nebulae and Star Clusters | edition= 2nd | publisher=Cambridge University Press | location=Cambridge | isbn=0-521-37079-5 }} [[w:Charles Messier]] added it to his catalogue of nebulous objects (now known as the [[w:Messier Catalogue]]) in March 1781. On [[w:16 June]] [[w:2008]] NASA's [[w:Galaxy Evolution Explorer]] project reported finding large numbers of new stars in the outer reaches of the galaxy. It had hitherto been thought that these areas lacked the materials necessary for star formation. [http://www.nasa.gov/mission_pages/galex/galex-20080416.html] ==Nearby galaxies and galaxy group information== M83 is at the center of one of two subgroups within the [[w:Centaurus A/M83 Group]], a nearby [[w:group of galaxies]].{{cite journal | author=I. D. Karachentsev, M. E. Sharina, A. E. Dolphin, E. K. Grebel, D. Geisler, P. Guhathakurta, P. W. Hodge, V. E. Karachetseva, A. Sarajedini, P. Seitzer | title=New distances to galaxies in the Centaurus A group | journal=Astronomy and Astrophysics | year=2002 | volume=385 | pages=21–31 | url=http://adsabs.harvard.edu/abs/2002A&A...385...21K | doi=10.1051/0004-6361:20020042}} [[w:Centaurus A]] is at the center of the other subgroup. These two groups are sometimes identified as one group{{cite book | author=R. B. Tully | year=1988 | title=Nearby Galaxies Catalog | edition= | publisher=Cambridge University Press | location=Cambridge | isbn=0-521-35299-1}}{{cite journal | author=P. Fouque, E. Gourgoulhon, P. Chamaraux, G. Paturel | title=Groups of galaxies within 80 Mpc. II - The catalogue of groups and group members | journal=Astronomy and Astrophysics Supplement | year=1992 | volume=93 | pages=211–233 | url=http://adsabs.harvard.edu/abs/1992A&AS...93..211F}} and sometimes identified as two groups.{{cite journal | author=A. Garcia | title=General study of group membership. II - Determination of nearby groups | journal=Astronomy and Astrophysics Supplement | year=1993 | volume=100 | pages=47–90 | url=http://adsabs.harvard.edu/abs/1993A&AS..100...47G}} However, the galaxies around Centaurus A and the galaxies around M83 are physically close to each other, and both subgroups appear not to be moving relative to each other.{{cite journal | author=I. D. Karachentsev | title=The Local Group and Other Neighboring Galaxy Groups | journal=Astronomical Journal | year=2005 | volume=129 | pages=178–188 | url=http://adsabs.harvard.edu/abs/2005AJ....129..178K | doi=10.1086/426368}} == External links == * [http://www.seds.org/messier/m/m083.html M83, SEDS Messier pages] * [http://ryutao.main.jp/english/st2k_m83_l.html Spiral Galaxy Messier 83 at the astro-photography site of '''Mr. Takayuki Yoshida.'''] * [http://www.dsi-astronomie.de/M83.html M83 The Southern Pinwheel] == References == {{Reflist}} {{Messier Index}}

revision.text:
{{Infobox galaxy | name = Virgo A | image = [[image:M87 jet.jpg|250px]] | caption = A 5000 [[w:Light-year|ly]] jet of matter ejected from M87 at near lightspeed. | epoch = [[w:J2000]] | constellation name = [[w:Virgo (constellation)|Virgo]] | ra = {{RA|12|30|49.4}}<ref name="ned">{{cite web | title=NASA/IPAC Extragalactic Database | work=Results for NGC 4486 | url=http://nedwww.ipac.caltech.edu/ | accessdate=2006-10-22}}</ref> | dec = {{DEC|+12|23|28}}<ref name="ned" /> | appmag_v = 9.59<ref name="ned" /> | type = E+0-1 pec<ref name="ned" />, NLRG Sy<ref name="ned" /> | names = Virgo A,<ref name="ned" /> [[w:New General Catalogue|NGC]] 4486,<ref name="ned" /> [[w:Uppsala General Catalogue|UGC]] 7654,<ref name="ned" /> [[w:Principal Galaxies Catalogue|PGC]] 41316,<ref name="ned" /> VCC 1316,<ref name="ned" /> [[w:Atlas of Peculiar Galaxies|Arp]] 152<ref name="ned" /> }}
'''Messier 87''' (also known as '''M87''', '''Virgo A''' or '''NGC 4486''') is a giant [[w:elliptical galaxy]]. The galaxy is the largest and brightest galaxy within the northern [[w:Virgo Cluster]], located about 55 million light years away.<ref>[http://adsabs.harvard.edu/cgi-bin/bib_query?1987AJ.....94..251B B. Binggeli, Bruno, G. A. Tammann, and A. Sandage, ''Astron. J.'' '''94''', 251 (1987).]</ref> The galaxy also contains a notable [[w:active galactic nucleus]] that is a strong source of multiwavelength radiation, particularly [[w:radio wave]]s.<ref name="baademinkowski1954">{{cite journal | author=W. Baade, R. Minkowski | title=On the Identification of Radio Sources | journal=Astrophysical Journal | year=1954 | volume=119 | pages=215–231 | url=http://adsabs.harvard.edu/abs/1954ApJ...119..215B | doi=10.1086/145813}}</ref> Since this is the largest giant elliptical galaxy near Earth and since it is one of the brightest radio sources in the sky, it is a popular target for both [[w:amateur astronomy]] observations and professional astronomy study. M87 is estimated to have a mass, within 32 kpc of its center, of 2.4 ± 0.6 {{e|12}} [[w:solar mass|M<sub>☉</sub>]].<ref name="Wuetal2006">{{cite journal | author=Wu, Xiaoan; Tremaine, Scott | title=Deriving the Mass Distribution of M87 from Globular Clusters | journal=The Astrophysical Journal | year=2006 | volume=643 | issue=1 | pages=210–221 | url=http://adsabs.harvard.edu/cgi-bin/nph-bib_query?bibcode=2006ApJ...643..210W | doi=10.1086/501515 }}</ref> Messier 87's diameter is a 120,000 light-years.
== Globular clusters == M87 has an unusually huge population (perhaps the greatest known around any one galaxy) of [[w:globular cluster]]s as compared to the [[w:Milky Way]]'s 150-200. A [[w:2006]] survey out to 25′ of its core estimates that there are 12,000 ± 800 globulars around M87.<ref name="Tamuraetal2006">{{cite journal | author=Tamura, Naoyuki; Sharples, Ray M.; Arimoto, Nobuo; Onodera, Masato; Ohta, Kouji; Yamada, Yoshihiko | title=A Subaru/Suprime-Cam wide-field survey of globular cluster populations around M87 - I. Observation, data analysis and luminosity function | journal=Monthly Notices of the Royal Astronomical Society | volume=Online Early | year=2006 | url=http://adsabs.harvard.edu/cgi-bin/nph-bib_query?doi=10.1111%2Fj.1365-2966.2006.11067.x | doi=10.1111/j.1365-2966.2006.11067.x | pages=588 }}</ref>
== Jet == In [[w:1918]], [[w:Lick Observatory]] astronomer [[w:Heber Curtis]] discovered a [[w:Relativistic jet|jet]] of matter coming from M87 which he described as "a curious straight ray." This jet extends at least 5000 light-years from the nucleus of M87 and is made up of matter ejected from the galaxy, most likely by a [[w:supermassive black hole]] (a hypothesis made more likely by the discovery of a disk of rapidly rotating gas around the nucleus of M87). [[w:Astronomer]]s believe that the black hole in this galaxy has a mass of approximately 6.4 billion (6.4×10<sup>9</sup>) [[w:solar mass]]es. M87 has also been found to be a strong source of [[w:X-ray]]s. Its proximity means that it is one of the best studied [[w:radio galaxy|radio galaxies]].
===Superluminal motion=== In pictures taken by the [[w:Hubble Space Telescope]] in [[w:1999]], the motion of M87's jet was measured at four to six times the speed of light. This motion is believed to be a visual result of the relativistic velocity of the jet, and not true [[w:superluminal motion]]. However, detection of such motion supports the theory that [[w:quasar]]s, [[w:BL Lac object]]s and [[w:radio galaxies]] may all be the same phenomenon, known as [[w:active galactic nucleus|active galaxies]], viewed from different perspectives.<ref>[http://www.journals.uchicago.edu/ApJ/journal/issues/ApJ/v520n2/39787/39787.html J. A. Biretta, W. B. Sparks, and F. Macchetto, ''Astrophys. J.'' '''520''', 621 (1999).;] {{cite web | title=Hubble detects faster-than-light motion in Galaxy M87 | author=John Biretta | publisher=Space Telecsope Science Institute | location=[[w:Baltimore, Maryland]] | url=http://www.stsci.edu/ftp/science/m87/press.txt | date=1999-01-06}}</ref>
===X-ray emitting loops and rings=== Observations made by [[w:Chandra X-ray Observatory]] indicate the presence of loops and rings in the hot X-ray emitting gas that permeate the cluster and surround M87. These loops and rings are generated by pressure waves. The pressure waves are caused by variations in the rate at which material is ejected from the [[w:supermassive black hole]] in jets. The distribution of loops suggests that minor eruptions occur every six million years. One of the rings, caused by a major eruption, is a shock wave 85,000 light-years in diameter around the black hole. Other remarkable features observed include narrow X-ray emitting filaments up to 100,000 light-years long, and a large cavity in the hot gas caused by a major eruption 70 million years ago. The regular eruptions prevent a huge reservoir of gas from cooling and forming stars, implying that M87’s evolution may have been seriously affected, preventing it from becoming a large [[w:Spiral galaxy]]. The observations also imply the presence of sound waves: 56 octaves below [[w:middle C]] for the minor eruptions and 58 to 59 below middle C for the major eruptions.<ref>[http://chandra.harvard.edu/press/06_releases/press_100506.html "Chandra Reviews Black Hole Musical: Epic But Off-Key"], [[w:October 2006]]</ref>
===Gamma ray emissions=== M87 is also a very strong source of [[w:gamma rays]], which are the most energetic rays of the electromagnetic spectrum; more than a million times as powerful as visible light. Gamma rays coming from M87 have been observed since the late 1990s, but recently, using the [[w:HESS]] Cherenkov telescopes, scientists have measured the variations of the gamma ray flux coming from M87, and found that the flux changes over a matter of days.
It is generally accepted that the supermassive [[w:black hole]] located in the center of M87 holds a mass of several billion solar masses. However, the fact that the variations can change over several days makes the immediate vicinity of the supermassive black hole in M87 (about the size of our [[w:solar system]])<ref>[http://www.universetoday.com/2006/10/27/gamma-rays-pour-from-the-edge-of-a-supermassive-black-hole/ Universe Today, Gamma Rays Pour From the Edge of a Supermassive Black Hole], [[w:October 2006]]</ref> the most promising source of the gamma rays. In general, the smaller the diameter, the faster the variations, and vice versa.
== External links == {{commons|Messier 87|Messier 87}} *[http://www.seds.org/messier/m/m087.html Messier 87], SEDS Messier pages *[http://simbad.u-strasbg.fr/sim-id.pl?Ident=M+87 Simbad data on M87] *[http://www.spacetelescope.org/news/html/heic0204.html ESA/Hubble News Release] *[http://www.spacetelescope.org/images/archive/freesearch/m87/viewall/1 ESA/Hubble images of M87] *[http://astro.neutral.org/imagehtml/20060304_m87.html Amateur Images of M87 Jet] *[http://www.starshadows.com/gallery/display.cfm?imgID=284 Another amateur image showing M87 jet and M87 globulars]
== References == {{reflist}}
{{Messier Index}}

revision.text:
{{Infobox galaxy | name = [[w:Messier object|Messier]] 90{{Ref|A|a}} | image = [[image:Messier 90.jpg|256px]] | caption = [[w:Messier object|Messier]] 90 | epoch = [[w:J2000]] | constellation name = [[w:Virgo (constellation)|Virgo]]<ref name="sinnott1988">{{cite book | author=R. W. Sinnott, editor | title= The Complete New General Catalogue and Index Catalogue of Nebulae and Star Clusters by J. L. E. Dreyer | year=1988 | publisher=Sky Publishing Corporation and Cambridge University Press | isbn=0-933-34651-4}}</ref> | ra = {{RA|12|36|49.8}}<ref name="ned">{{cite web | title=NASA/IPAC Extragalactic Database | work=Results for NGC 205 | url=http://nedwww.ipac.caltech.edu/ | accessdate=2006-02-01}}</ref> | dec = {{DEC|+13|09|46}}<ref name="ned" /> | appmag_v = 10.26<ref name="ned" /> | type = SAB(rs)ab<ref name="ned" />, [[w:LINER]]<ref name="ned" />, Sy<ref name="ned" /> | names = [[w:New General Catalogue|NGC]] 4569,<ref name="ned" /> [[w:Uppsala General Catalogue|UGC]] 7786,<ref name="ned" /> [[w:Principal Galaxies Catalogue|PGC]] 42089,<ref name="ned" /> [[w:Atlas of Peculiar Galaxies|Arp]] 76<ref name="ned" /> }}
'''Messier 90''' (also known as ''M90'' and ''NGC 4569'') is a [[w:spiral galaxy]] about 60 million [[w:light-year]]s away in the [[w:constellation]] [[w:Virgo (constellation)|Virgo]]. It was discovered by [[w:Charles Messier]] in [[w:1781]].<ref name="jones1991">{{cite book | author=K. G. Jones | year=1991 | title=Messier's Nebulae and Star Clusters | edition= 2nd | publisher=Cambridge University Press | location=Cambridge | isbn=0-521-37079-5 }}</ref>
== Membership of the Virgo Cluster == Messier 90 is a member of the [[w:Virgo Cluster]].<ref name="binggelietal1985">{{cite journal | author= B. Binggeli, A. Sandage, G. A. Tammann | title=Studies of the Virgo Cluster. II - A catalog of 2096 galaxies in the Virgo Cluster area | journal=Astronomical Journal | year=1985 | volume=90 | pages=1681–1759 | url=http://adsabs.harvard.edu/abs/1985AJ.....90.1681B | doi= 10.1086/113874 }}</ref> The galaxy is located approximately 1°.5 away from the subgroup centered on [[w:Messier 87]].<ref name="carnegieatlas">{{cite book | author=A. Sandage, J. Bedke | year=1994 | title=Carnegie Atlas of Galaxies | publisher=Carnegie Institution of Washington | location=Washington, D.C. | isbn=0-87279-667-1}}</ref> As a consequence of the galaxy's interaction with the [[w:intracluster medium]] in the Virgo Cluster, the galaxy has lost much of its [[w:interstellar medium]]. As a result of this process, which is referred to as ''ram pressure stripping'', the galaxy's interstellar medium and [[w:star formation|star formation region]]s appear truncated compared to similar galaxies outside the Virgo Cluster.<ref name="koopmannkenney2004">{{cite journal | author= R. A. Koopmann, J. D. P. Kenney | title=Hα Morphologies and Environmental Effects in Virgo Cluster Spiral Galaxies | journal=Astrophysical Journal | year=2004 | volume=613 | pages=866–885 | url=http://adsabs.harvard.edu/abs/2004ApJ...613..866K | doi= 10.1086/423191 }}</ref>
== Star formation activity == As stated above, the [[w:star formation]] in Messier 90 appears truncated. Consequently, the galaxy's spiral arms appear to be smooth and featureless, rather than knotted like galaxies with extended star formation.<ref name="koopmannkenney2004" /> However, the center of Messier 90 appears to be a site of significant star formation activity. Multiple [[w:supernovae]] in the nucleus have produced 'superwinds' that are blowing the galaxy's interstellar medium outward into the intracluster medium.<ref name="tschokeetal2001">{{cite journal | author=D. Tschöke, D. J. Bomans, G. Hensler, N. Junkes | title=Hot halo gas in the Virgo cluster galaxy NGC 4569 | journal=Astronomy and Astrophysics | year=2001 | volume=380 | pages=40–54 | url=http://adsabs.harvard.edu/abs/2001A&A...380...40T | doi=10.1051/0004-6361:20011354 }}</ref>
== Blueshift == The [[w:spectrum]] of Messier 90 is [[w:blueshift]]ed, which indicates that it is moving towards the Earth.<ref name="ned" /> In contrast, the spectra of most other galaxies are [[w:redshift]]ed. The blueshift was originally used to argue that Messier 90 was actually an object in the foreground of the Virgo Cluster. However, since the phenomenon was limited mostly to galaxies in the same part of the sky as the Virgo Cluster, it appeared that this inference based on the blueshift was incorrect. Instead, the blueshift is thought to be evidence for the large range in velocities of objects within the Virgo Cluster itself.<ref name="carnegieatlas" />
== Distance measurements == Low levels of [[w:H I]] gas prevents using the [[w:Tully-Fisher relation]] to estimate the distance to Messier 90.<ref name="tschokeetal2001" />
== Companion galaxies == Messier 90 has a [[w:satellite galaxy]] ([[w:IC 3583]]) which is an [[w:irregular galaxy]]{{Fact|date=February 2007}}.
== External links == * [http://www.seds.org/messier/m/m090.html SEDS: Spiral Galaxy M90]
== Notes == :{{Note|A|a}}{{Harvnb|Tschöke|Bomans|Hensler|Junkes|2001}} uses a [[w:Hubble constant]] of 75 (km/s)/Mpc to estimate a distance of 16.8 Mpc to NGC 4569. Adjusting for the 2006 value of 70{{±|2.4|3.2}} (km/s)/Mpc we get a distance of 18.0{{±|0.9|0.6}} Mpc.
== References == {{reflist}}
{{Messier Index}}

{{ Globular cluster | | name = [[w:Messier object|Messier]] 92 | image = | caption = An image of M92, taken with a [[w:Ritchey-Chrétien telescope|20" RC telescope]] | credit = Achut Reddy/Flynn Haase/[[w:NOAO]]/[[w:AURA]]/[[w:National Science Foundation|NSF]] | epoch = [[w:J2000]] | class = | constellation = [[w:Hercules constellation|Hercules]] | ra = {{RA|17|17|07.27}}{{cite web | title=SIMBAD Astronomical Database | work=Results for NGC 6341 | url=http://simbad.u-strasbg.fr/Simbad | accessdate=2006-11-17}} | dec = {{DEC|+43|08|11.5}} | dist_ly = 26 [[w:light year|kly]]{{Fact|date=February 2007}} | dist_pc = 8 [[w:parsec|kpc]] | appmag_v = +6.3 | size_v = | mass_kg = | mass_msol = | radius_ly = | v_hb = | age = | notes = | names = M92, [[w:New General Catalogue|NGC]] 6341, GCl 59 }} '''Messier 92''' (also known as ''M92'' or ''NGC 6341'') is a [[w:globular cluster]] in the [[w:Hercules constellation|constellation Hercules]]. It was discovered by [[w:Johann Elert Bode]] in [[w:1777]] and independently rediscovered by [[w:Charles Messier]] on [[w:March 18]], [[w:1781]]. M92 is at a distance of about 26,000 [[w:light-year]]s away from [[w:Earth]]. [[image:M92 Hubble WikiSky.jpg|thumb|left|200px|Center of M92 by [[w:Hubble Space Telescope|HST]]; 1.44′ view]] [[image:M92HunterWilson.jpg|thumb|left|200px|Messier 92. Courtesy Hunter Wilson]] M92 is one of the brighter globular clusters in the northern hemisphere, but it is often overlooked by amateur astronomers because of its proximity to the even more spectacular [[w:Messier 13]]. ==External links== * [http://www.seds.org/messier/m/m092.html Messier 92 @ SEDS Messier pages] * [http://venus.mporzio.astro.it/~marco/gc/cluster_4.php?ggc=M+92 Messier 92, Galactic Globular Clusters Database page] ==References==
{{Messier Index}}

{{Infobox galaxy | name = [[w:Messier object|Messier]] 94<ref name="tonryetal2001">{{cite journal | author=J. L. Tonry, A. Dressler, J. P. Blakeslee, E. A. Ajhar, A. B. Fletcher, G. A. Luppino, M. R. Metzger, C. B. Moore | title=The SBF Survey of Galaxy Distances. IV. SBF Magnitudes, Colors, and Distances | journal=Astrophysical Journal | year=2001 | volume=546 | issue=2 | pages=681–693 | url=http://adsabs.harvard.edu/abs/2001ApJ...546..681T | doi=10.1086/318301 }}</ref><ref name="karachentsevetal2003">{{cite journal | author=I. D. Karachentsev, M. E. Sharina, A. E. Dolphin, E. K. Grebel, D. Geisler, P. Guhathakurta, P. W. Hodge, V. E. Karachentseva, A. Sarajedini, P. Seitzer | title=Galaxy flow in the Canes Venatici I cloud | journal=Astronomy and Astrophysics | year=2003 | volume=398 | pages=467–477 | url=http://adsabs.harvard.edu/abs/2003A&A...398..467K | doi=10.1051/0004-6361:20021598 }}</ref><ref name="averageCalc">average(17.0 ± 1.4, 15 ± 2) = ((17.0 + 15) / 2) ± ((1.4<sup>2</sup> + 2<sup>2</sup>)<sup>0.5</sup> / 2) = 16.0 ± 1.3</ref> | image = [[File:Messier object 094.jpg]] | caption = M94: Atlas Image courtesy of 2MASS/UMass/IPAC-Caltech/NASA/NSF | epoch = [[w:J2000|J2000]] | constellation name = [[w:Canes Venatici (constellation)|Canes Venatici]]<ref name="sinnott1988">{{cite book | author=R. W. Sinnott, editor | title= The Complete New General Catalogue and Index Catalogue of Nebulae and Star Clusters by J. L. E. Dreyer | year=1988 | publisher=Sky Publishing Corporation and Cambridge University Press | isbn=0-933-34651-4}}</ref> | ra = {{RA|12|50|53.1}} <ref name="ned">{{cite web | title=NASA/IPAC Extragalactic Database | work=Results for M94 | url=http://nedwww.ipac.caltech.edu/ | accessdate=2006-11-09}}</ref> | dec = {{DEC|+41|07|14}} <ref name="ned" /> | appmag_v = 8.99 <ref name="ned" /> | type = (R)SA(r)ab<ref name="ned" />, [[w:LINER|LINER]]<ref name="ned" /> | names = [[w:New General Catalogue|NGC]] 4736, [[w:Uppsala General Catalogue|UGC]] 7996, [[w:Principal Galaxies Catalogue|PGC]] 43495<ref name="ned" /> }}
'''Messier 94''' (also known as ''NGC 4736'') is a [[w:spiral galaxy|spiral galaxy]] in the [[w:constellation|constellation]] [[w:Canes Venatici|Canes Venatici]]. It was discovered by [[w:Pierre Méchain|Pierre Méchain]] in [[w:1781|1781]],<ref name="NSOG">{{cite book |last= Kepple |first= George Robert |coauthors= Glen W. Sanner |title= The Night Sky Observer's Guide, Volume 2 |publisher= Willmann-Bell, Inc. |year= 1998 |isbn= 0-943396-60-3 |page=51 }}</ref> and catalogued by [[w:Charles Messier|Charles Messier]] two days later. Although some references describe M94 as a [[w:barred spiral galaxy|barred spiral galaxy]], the "bar" structure appears to be more oval-shaped.<ref name="kormendykennicutt04">{{cite journal | author=J. Kormendy, R. C. Kennicutt, Jr. | title=Secular Evolution and the Formation of Pseudobulges in Disk Galaxies | journal=Annual Reviews of Astronomy and Astrophysics | year=2004 | volume=42 | pages=603–683 | url=http://adsabs.harvard.edu/abs/2004ARA&A..42..603K | doi=10.1146/annurev.astro.42.053102.134024 }}</ref> The galaxy is also notable in that it has two ring structures.<ref name="ned" />
==Nucleus== M94 is classified as having a [[w:low ionization nuclear emission region|low ionization nuclear emission region]] (LINER) nucleus.<ref name="hoetal1997">{{cite journal | author= L. C. Ho, A. V. Filippenko, W. L. W. Sargent | title=A Search for "Dwarf" Seyfert Nuclei. III. Spectroscopic Parameters and Properties of the Host Galaxies | journal=Astrophysical Journal Supplement | year=1997 | volume=112 | pages=315–390 | url=http://adsabs.harvard.edu/abs/1997ApJS..112..315H | doi= 10.1086/313041 }}</ref> LINERs in general are characterized by optical [[w:spectrum|spectra]] that reveal that [[w:ion|ion]]ized gas is present but the gas is only weakly ionized (i.e. the atoms are missing relatively few electrons).
==Inner and outer rings== M94 contains both an inner ring with a diameter of 70" and an outer ring with a diameter of 600". These rings appear to form at [[w:resonance|resonance]] locations within the disk of the galaxy. The inner ring is the site of strong [[w:star formation|star formation]] activity and is sometimes referred to as a [[w:starburst (astronomy)|starburst]] ring. This star formation is fueled by gas that is dynamically driven into the ring by the inner oval-shaped bar-like structure.<ref name="munoztunonetal04">{{cite journal | author=C. Muñoz-Tuñón, N. Caon, J. Aguerri, L. Alfonso | title=The Inner Ring of NGC 4736: Star Formation on a Resonant Pattern | journal=Astronomical Journal | year=2004 | volume=127 | pages=58–74 | url=http://adsabs.harvard.edu/abs/2004AJ....127...58M | doi=10.1086/380610}}</ref>
==Pseudobulge== In a paper published in 2004, [[w:John Kormendy|John Kormendy]] and [[w:Robert Kennicutt|Robert Kennicutt]] argued that M94 contains a prototypical [[w:bulge (astronomy)|pseudobulge]].<ref name="kormendykennicutt04" /> A classical [[w:spiral galaxy|spiral galaxy]] consists of a disk of gas and young stars that intersects a large sphere (or bulge) of older stars. In contrast, a galaxy with a pseudobulge does not have a large bulge of old stars but instead contain a bright central structure with intense star formation that looks like a bulge when the galaxy is viewed face-on. In the case of M94, this pseudobulge takes the form of a ring around a central oval-shaped region.
==Distance measurements== At least two techniques have been used to measure distances to M94. The [[w:surface brightness fluctuation|surface brightness fluctuation]]s distance measurement technique estimates distances to spiral galaxies based on the graininess of the appearance of their bulges. The distance measured to M94 using this technique is 17.0 ± 1.4 [[w:light-year|Mly]] (5.2 ± 0.4 [[w:parsec|Mpc]]).<ref name="tonryetal2001" /> However, M94 is close enough that the [[w:Hubble Space Telescope|Hubble Space Telescope]] can be used to resolve and measure the fluxes of the brightest individual stars within the galaxy. These measured fluxes can then be compared to the measured fluxes of similar stars within the [[w:Milky Way|Milky Way]] to measure the distance. The estimated distance to M94 using this technique is 15 ± 2 [[w:light-year|Mly]] (4.7 ± 0.6 [[w:parsec|Mpc]]).<ref name="karachentsevetal2003" /> Averaged together, these distance measurements give a distance estimate of 16.0 ± 1.3 [[w:light-year|Mly]] (4.9 ± 0.4 [[w:parsec|Mpc]]).
==Dark matter== In 2008 a study was published <ref name="bratek">{{cite journal | author=J. Jałocha, Ł. Bratek, and M. Kutschera | title=Is Dark Matter Present in NGC 4736? An Iterative Spectral Method for Finding Mass Distribution in Spiral Galaxies | journal=The Astrophysical Journal | year=2008 | volume=679 | pages=373–378 | url=http://de.arxiv.org/pdf/astro-ph/0611113v3 | doi=10.1086/533511}}</ref> that appeared to show that M94 had very little or no [[w:dark matter|dark matter]] present. The study analyzed the rotation curves of the galaxy's stars and the density of hydrogen gas and found that ordinary luminous matter appeared to account for all of the galaxy's mass. This result was unusual and somewhat controversial, as current models don't indicate how a galaxy could form without a dark matter halo or how a galaxy could lose its dark matter. Other explanations for galactic rotation curves, such as [[w:MOND|MOND]], also have difficulty explaining this galaxy.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://space.newscientist.com/article/dn13280-galaxy-without-dark-matter-puzzles-astronomers.html| title=Galaxy without dark matter puzzles astronomers| date= 06 February 2008| publisher= NewScientist.com news service| first= Stephen | last=Battersby}}</ref>
==Galaxy group information== M94 is one of the brightest galaxies within the [[w:M94 Group|M94 Group]], a [[w:group of galaxies|group of galaxies]] that contains between 16 and 24 galaxies.<ref name="nbg">{{cite book | author=R. B. Tully | year=1988 | title=Nearby Galaxies Catalog | edition= | publisher=Cambridge University Press | location=Cambridge | isbn=0-521-35299-1}}</ref><ref name="garcia1993">{{cite journal | author=A. Garcia | title=General study of group membership. II - Determination of nearby groups | journal=Astronomy and Astrophysics Supplement | year=1993 | volume=100 | pages=47–90 | url=http://adsabs.harvard.edu/abs/1993A&AS..100...47G}}</ref><ref name="giuricinetal2002">{{cite journal | author=G. Giuricin, C. Marinoni, L. Ceriani, A. Pisani | title=Nearby Optical Galaxies: Selection of the Sample and Identification of Groups | journal=Astrophysical Journal | year=2000 | volume=543 | pages=178–194 | url=http://adsabs.harvard.edu/abs/2000ApJ...543..178G | doi=10.1086/317070 }}</ref> This group is one of many that lies within the [[w:Virgo Supercluster|Virgo Supercluster]] (i.e. the [[w:Local Supercluster|Local Supercluster]]).<ref name="tully1982">{{cite journal | author= R. B. Tully | title=The Local Supercluster | journal=Astrophysical Journal | year=1982 | volume=257 | pages=389–422 | url=http://adsabs.harvard.edu/abs/1982ApJ...257..389T | doi= 10.1086/159999 }}</ref> Although a large number of galaxies may be associated with M94, only a few galaxies near M94 appear to form a gravitationally bound system. Most of the other nearby galaxies appear to be moving with the expansion of the universe.<ref name="karachentsevetal2003" /><ref name="karachentsev2005">{{cite journal | author=I. D. Karachentsev | title=The Local Group and Other Neighboring Galaxy Groups | journal=Astronomical Journal | year=2005 | volume=129 | pages=178–188 | url=http://adsabs.harvard.edu/abs/2005AJ....129..178K | doi=10.1086/426368 }}</ref>
== External links == * [http://ryutao.main.jp/english/st2k_m94.html Galaxy Messier 94 at the astro-photography site of Mr. T. Yoshida.] * [http://www.seds.org/messier/m/m094.html SEDS: Spiral Galaxy M94]
==References== {{reflist}}
{{Messier Index}}

{{ Planetary nebula | name = Messier 97 | image = |caption= Credit: Robert J. Vanderbei | name = Owl Nebula | type = 3a | epoch = J2000.0 | ra = 11h 14.8m | dec = +55° 01′ | dist_ly = [[w:1 E22 m|2,600]] [[w:light year|ly]] | appmag_v = +9.9 | size_v = 3.4 × 3.3 [[w:Minute of arc|arcmin]] | constellation = Ursa Major | radius_ly = 1.5 [[w:light year|ly]] | absmag_v = - | notes = Owl-like "eyes" visible through larger telescopes | names = M97, NGC 3587}} The '''Owl Nebula''' (also known as '''[[w:Messier Object]] 97''' or '''[[w:New_General_Catalogue|NGC]] 3587''') is a [[w:planetary nebula]] in the [[w:constellation]] [[w:Ursa Major]]. It was discovered by [[w:Pierre Méchain]] in 1781. M97 is regarded as one of the more complex of the planetaries. The 16th [[w:apparent magnitude|magnitude]] central [[w:star]] has about 0.7 [[w:solar mass]] and the nebula itself about 0.15 solar mass. The nebula formed roughly 6,000 years ago. The nebula gets it name due to the appearance of owl-like "eyes" when view through a large (>200 mm) telescope under dark sky conditions with the aid of a so-called "nebula filter." The "eyes" are also easily visible through photographs taken of the nebula. [[image:M97 FTN.jpg|250px|thumb|left|Image of Messier 97 taken with red, green
and blue filters with the [[w:Faulkes Telescope North]]]] ==External links== * [http://www.seds.org/messier/m/m097.html The Owl Nebula @ SEDS Messier pages] * [http://www.nightskyinfo.com/archive/owl_nebula NightSkyInfo.com - M97, the Owl Nebula] * [http://www.stargazer-observatory.com/M97-9.html M97, imaged with a semiprofessional amateur-telescope] {{Messier Index}}

{{Infobox galaxy | name = [[w:Messier object|Messier]] 99 | image = [[image:M99atlas.jpg|300px]] |caption = A [[w:near-infrared]] image of M99.
Credit: [[w:2MASS]]/[[w:NASA]]. | constellation name = [[w:Coma Berenices]]{{cite book | author=R. W. Sinnott, editor | title= The Complete New General Catalogue and Index Catalogue of Nebulae and Star Clusters by J. L. E. Dreyer | year=1988 | publisher=Sky Publishing Corporation and Cambridge University Press | isbn=0-933-34651-4}} | epoch = [[w:J2000]] | type = SA(s)c{{cite web | title=NASA/IPAC Extragalactic Database | work=Results for NGC 4254 | url=http://nedwww.ipac.caltech.edu/ | accessdate=2006-11-25 }} | ra = {{RA|12|18|49.6}} | dec = {{DEC|+14|24|59}} | dist_ly = [[w:1 E23 m|60]] [[w:light-year|Mly]]{{Fact|date=February 2007}} | z = 2407 ± 3 km/[[w:second|s]] | appmag_v = 10.4 | size_v = 5′.4 × 4′.7 | notes = | names = [[w:New General Catalogue|NGC]] 4254, [[w:Uppsala General Catalogue|UGC]] 7345, [[w:Principal Galaxies Catalogue|PGC]] 39578, Coma Pinwheel Galaxy,{{cite web | title=SIMBAD Astronomical Database | work=Results for NGC 4254 | url=http://simbad.u-strasbg.fr/Simbad | accessdate=2006-11-25}} Virgo Cluster Pinwheel }} '''Messier 99''' (also known as ''M99'' or ''NGC 4254'') is an [[w:unbarred spiral galaxy]] approximately [[w:1 E23 m|60 million]] [[w:light-year]]s away in the [[w:constellation]] [[w:Coma Berenices]]. The galaxy has a normal looking arm and an extended arm that is less tightly wound. A bridge of neutral hydrogen gas links NGC 4254 with [[w:VIRGOHI21]]. The gravity from the [[w:dark galaxy]] [[w:VIRGOHI21]] appears to have distorted M99 and drawn out the gas bridge, as the two galaxy-sized objects have a close encounter, before they go their separate ways. It is expected that the drawn out arm will relax to match the normal arm once the encounter is over. Three supernovae have been observed in this galaxy. [[image:M99HunterWilson.jpg|thumb|left|500px|Amateur Image of '''Messier 99''' Courtesy Hunter Wilson]] ==History== Messier 99 was discovered by [[w:Pierre Méchain]] on [[w:March 17]], [[w:1781]]. The discovery was then reported to [[w:Charles Messier]], who included the object in the [[w:Messier Catalogue]], which was the first astronomical catalogue of star clusters, nebulae, and galaxies.{{cite book | author=K. G. Jones | year=1991 | title=Messier's Nebulae and Star Clusters | edition= 2nd edition | publisher=Cambridge University Press | location=Cambridge | isbn=0-521-37079-5 }} Messier 99 was one of the first galaxies in which a spiral pattern was first seen. The spiral pattern was first identified by [[w:Lord Rosse]] in the mid-nineteenth century. == External links == * [http://www.seds.org/messier/m/m099.html SEDS: Spiral Galaxy M99] * [http://www.universetoday.com/am/publish/pparc_darkmatter_virgohi.html?1212006 UniverseToday: Dark Matter Galaxy?] * [http://www.pparc.ac.uk/Nw/d_galaxy2.asp PPARC: New evidence for a Dark Matter Galaxy] ==References== {{reflist}} {{Messier Index}}

{{Infobox galaxy | name = Pinwheel Galaxy | image = [[image:M101 hires STScI-PRC2006-10a.jpg|300px]] |caption = The Pinwheel Galaxy. Credit: [[w:NASA]]/[[w:European Space Agency|ESA]] | epoch = [[w:J2000]] | constellation name = [[w:Ursa Major]]<ref name="sinnott1988">{{cite book | author=R. W. Sinnott, editor | title= The Complete New General Catalogue and Index Catalogue of Nebulae and Star Clusters by J. L. E. Dreyer | year=1988 | publisher=Sky Publishing Corporation and Cambridge University Press | isbn=0-933-34651-4}}</ref> | ra = {{RA|14|03|12.6}}<ref name="ned" /> | dec = {{DEC|+54|20|57}}<ref name="ned" /> | type = SAB(rs)cd<ref name="ned">{{cite web | title=NASA/IPAC Extragalactic Database | work=Results for NGC 5457 | url=http://nedwww.ipac.caltech.edu/ | accessdate=2006-12-06}}</ref> | dist_ly = [[w:1 E22 m|27]] [[w:light-year|Mly]]{{Fact|date=February 2007}} | appmag_v = 8.3<ref name="ned" /> | size_v = 28′.8 × 26′.9<ref name="ned" /> | z = 241 ± 2 km/[[w:second|s]]<ref name="ned" /> | notes = | names = [[w:Messier object|Messier]] 101,<ref name="ned" /> [[w:New General Catalogue|NGC]] 5457,<ref name="ned" /> [[w:Uppsala General Catalogue|UGC]] 8981,<ref name="ned" /> [[w:Principal Galaxies Catalogue|PGC]] 50063,<ref name="ned" /> [[w:Atlas of Peculiar Galaxies|Arp]] 26<ref name="ned" /> }}
The '''Pinwheel Galaxy''' (also known as '''Messier 101''' or '''NGC 5457''') is a face-on [[w:spiral galaxy]] about 27 million [[w:light-year]]s away in the [[w:constellation]] [[w:Ursa Major]].
It was discovered by [[w:Pierre Méchain]] on [[w:March 27]], [[w:1781]], and he subsequently communicated his discovery to [[w:Charles Messier]] who verified its position and added it to the [[w:Messier Catalogue]] as one of the final entries.
On [[w:February 28]], [[w:2006]], [[w:NASA]] and the [[w:ESA]] released a very detailed image of Pinwheel Galaxy, which was the largest and most detailed image of a galaxy by [[w:Hubble Space Telescope]] at the time.<ref>[http://hubblesite.org/newscenter/newsdesk/archive/releases/2006/10/ HubbleSite - NewsCenter - Hubble's Largest Galaxy Portrait Offers a New High-Definition View (02/28/2006) - Introduction<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> The image was composed from 51 individual exposures, plus some extra ground-based photos.
== Discovery == Pierre Méchain, the discoverer of M101, described it as a "nebula without star, very obscure and pretty large, 6' to 7' in diameter, between the left hand of Bootes and the tail of the great Bear. It is difficult to distinguish when one lits the [grating] wires."<ref name="SEDS Historical Notes">SEDS Historical Notes, [http://www.seds.org/messier/Mdes/dm101.html]</ref>
[[w:William Herschel]] noted in 1784 that "[M101] in my 7, 10, and 20-feet reflectors shewed a mottled kind of nebulosity, which I shall call resolvable; so that I expect my present telescope will, perhaps, render the stars visible of which I suppose them to be composed."<ref name="SEDS Historical Notes"/>
[[w:Lord Rosse]] observed M101 in his 72-inch [[w:Newtonian telescope|Newtonian reflector]] during the second half of the 19th century. He was the first to make extensive note of the spiral structure and made several sketches.<ref name="SEDS Historical Notes"/>
To observe the spiral structure in modern instruments requires a fairly large instrument, very dark skies, and a low power eye piece.
== Structure and composition == [[image:Anttlers101.jpg||thumb|left|300px|The Pinwheel Galaxy. Credit: Scott Anttila.]]
M101 is a relatively large galaxy compared to the [[w:Milky Way]]. With a diameter of 170,000 light-years it is nearly twice the size of the Milky Way. It has a disk mass on the order of 100 billion solar masses, along with a small bulge of about 3 billion solar masses<ref name="M101 mass"> Comte, G., Monnet, G., & Rosado, M. "An optical study of the galaxy M 101 - Derivation of a mass model from the kinematic of the gas," 1979, ''Astronomy & Astrophysics'', '''72''', 73-81 ([http://adsabs.harvard.edu/abs/1979A%26A....72...73C])</ref>
Another remarkable property of this galaxy is its huge and extremely bright [[w:H II region|H II regions]] , of which a total of about 3000 can be seen on photographs. HII regions usually accompany the enormous clouds of high density molecular hydrogen gas contracting under their own gravitational force where [[w:star formation|stars form]]. HII regions are ionized by large numbers of extremely bright and hot young stars.
On photographs M101 can be seen to be asymmetrical on one side. It is thought that in the recent past (speaking in galactic terms) M101 underwent a near collision with another galaxy and the associated gravitational [[w:tidal]] forces caused the asymmetry. In addition, this encounter also amplified the density waves in the spiral arms of M101. The amplification of these waves leads to the compression of the [[w:interstellar medium|interstellar hydrogen gas]], which then triggers strong [[w:star formation]] activity.
== Companion galaxies == M101 has five prominent companion galaxies: [[w:NGC 5204]], [[w:NGC 5474]], [[w:NGC 5477]], [[w:NGC 5585]], and [[w:Holmberg IV]].<ref name="carnegieatlas" >{{cite book | author=A. Sandage, J. Bedke | year=1994 | title=Carnegie Atlas of Galaxies | edition= | publisher=Carnegie Institution of Washington | location=Washington, D.C. | isbn=0-87279-667-1 }}</ref> As stated above, the gravitational interaction between M101 and its satellites may have triggered the formation of the grand design pattern in M101. M101 has also probably distorted the companion galaxy NGC 5474.<ref name="carnegieatlas"/> M101 and its companion galaxies comprise most or possibly all of the [[w:M101 Group]].<ref name="nbg">{{cite book | author=R. B. Tully | year=1988 | title=Nearby Galaxies Catalog | edition= | publisher=Cambridge University Press | location=Cambridge | isbn=0-521-35299-1}}</ref><ref name="fouqueetal1992">{{cite journal | author=P. Fouque, E. Gourgoulhon, P. Chamaraux, G. Paturel | title=Groups of galaxies within 80 Mpc. II - The catalogue of groups and group members | journal=Astronomy and Astrophysics Supplement | year=1992 | volume=93 | pages=211–233 | url=http://adsabs.harvard.edu/abs/1992A&AS...93..211F}}</ref><ref name="garcia1993">{{cite journal | author=A. Garcia | title=General study of group membership. II - Determination of nearby groups | journal=Astronomy and Astrophysics Supplement | year=1993 | volume=100 | pages=47–90 | url=http://adsabs.harvard.edu/abs/1993A&AS..100...47G}}</ref><ref name="giuricinetal2002">{{cite journal | author=G. Giuricin, C. Marinoni, L. Ceriani, A. Pisani | title=Nearby Optical Galaxies: Selection of the Sample and Identification of Groups | journal=Astrophysical Journal | year=2000 | volume=543 | pages=178–194 | url=http://adsabs.harvard.edu/abs/2000ApJ...543..178G | doi=10.1086/317070}}</ref>

Credit: HST/NASA/ESA. | constellation name = Virgo<ref name="sinnott1988">{{cite book | author=R. W. Sinnott, editor | title= The Complete New General Catalogue and Index Catalogue of Nebulae and Star Clusters by J. L. E. Dreyer | year=1988 | publisher=Sky Publishing Corporation and Cambridge University Press | id=ISBN 0-933-34651-4}}</ref> | epoch = J2000 | ra = {{RA|12|39|59.4}}<ref name="ned">{{cite web | title=NASA/IPAC Extragalactic Database | work=Results for NGC 4594 | url=http://nedwww.ipac.caltech.edu/ | accessdate=2006-11-22}}</ref> | dec = {{DEC|-11|37|23}}<ref name="ned" /> | dist_ly = 29.3 ± 1.6 Mly (9.0 ± 0.5 Mpc)<ref name="fordetal1996">{{cite journal | author=H.
